reviews.review: Blood, gore and violence rich gameplay. All you have to do is survive at all costs. If you can digest these things, you better watch out what your teammates have in mind for you.
A fun game to play both alone and with friends

While I've admittedly not played as much as a lot of people in the community, I have been playing for a while. About a year and a half maybe, around when Ash came out. Ever since I started, there's been a stead decline in the quality of the game, so unfortunately I'm going to have to leave a negative review for the game in its current state. Unbalanced mechanics like Moris and Keys, bugs that take weeks to fix while premium content is pumped out constantly, and a broken matchmaking system that hardly ever works. This isn't even taking into account the toxicity between both the Killer and Survivor sides, and for good reason. One shot huntress, infinite tier 3 Myers, Decisive Strike, Unbreakable, Adrenaline, NOED, Pop Goes the Weasel, Legion, Nurse, Object of Obsession, gen speeds, camping/tunneling, the list goes on and on.

Furthermore, the developers are both ignorant and/or outright refuse to listen to the community. Almost all of the issues I've listed above have been complained about for a long, long time; and the developer streams show that they're not really concerned with any of that. Instead, almost every aspect of the game has to be monetized to near EA levels. Cosmetics going up to almost $20 for one is absurd, not to mention the "sets" that force people to spend more if they want a specific part of it. They also introduced a battle pass last year, which is mostly full of useless charms that almost never get more than a passing glance. They've even stooped to making their events centric around sales and the battle pass itself, for example look no further than the recent abhorrent Halloween event. 

To get a new character (and their perks, which are crucial for the game) you need to either cough up $5 (a necessity for licensed characters) or grind out 9000 Iridescent Shards, which is a pretty damn good chunk of gameplay. There are currently 37 characters locked by default that you either have to pay for ($185 for all of them) or grind out each one very slowly, one by one. The leveling system is also outdated as hell, and requires even more grinding from the player just to get one character to a semi-playable state. You know it's bad when the mobile port has a better leveling system, better coding, and a better reception to community feedback than the original PC game does.

All in all, the game has way too many problems right now for me to recommend it to anyone thinking of picking it up right now. A vast majority of the perks and killer need a big overhaul, either to make them less powerful or more viable than useless. The monetization of the games needs to be brought down hard. The Bloodweb (leveling) system and currency gain need to be reworked. And finally, the developers really need to start getting their act together and start listening to the community so they can make the game better for everyone involved. Until then, the game is a toxic cesspool that no longer holds the charm it used to have.
